> That's cool...elaborate, if you would!

Certainly;

This is not the first genetic art evolver, I think Karl Simms was first,
though Richard Dawkins did some early work. It's not even my first genetic
art evolver, it's like my third or something.

Anyway, I feed the neural network with the coordinates of each pixel and
let the network output the shade of that pixel.

The user clicks on the picture that he likes and hits "New Generation". A
new batch of images is created using the fitness specified by the user.

If the user clicks on may images, they may be crossed over in a few of the
next generation images.

This program violates a few of the NEAT advantages;
 * It doesn't use species (there'd be not point)
 * It doesn't start minimally (that would be dull)

I've put up a version here;
http://www.CambrianLabs.com/Mattias/DelphiNEAT/File/GeneticArt.zip

Be warned, it's very rough and you can't save nor load images. So if you
evolve the best image ever, man, it's gone!

cheers,
mattias
